STATE TREASURER'S REPORT December 1, 1918 — November SO, 1920 TREASURY DEPARTMENT, STATE OF NEBRASKA Lincoln, December 1, 1920. To His Excellency, The Governor of Nebraska and The 40th Session of the Legislature, Sirs In compliance with the law, I have the honor to transmit here- with the biennial report of the transaction of the Treasury Depart- ment of the State of Nebraska, for the biennium ending November 30, 1920. It would appear that the Department handled approximately flify million dollars, having received to the amount of about twenty-five million dollars and a like amount disbursed, as shown by the follow- ing detailed statement: RECEIPTS Balance on hand December 1, 1918 $ 1,392,019.43 Less Overdraft 523,275.23 Net Balance $ 868,744.20 Receipts from Dec. 1, 1918, to Nov. 30, 1920.- 25,239,505.65 $26,108,249. 85 DISBURSEMENTS Balance on hand November 30, 1920 $ 2,770,861.99 Less Overdraft November 30, 1920 2,089,631.56 Net Balance $ 681,230.56 Disbursements from December 1, 1918, to No- vember 30, 1920 25,427,019.29 $26,108,249.85

4 REPORT OF I would recommend to the Legislature that the $790,000 of State of Massachusetts bonds, which run for twenty years to come and are drawing 3 and 3 % % interest, be sold, and that the Legislature make an appropriation to pay the discount. This money could be re-invested in School District and Municipal bonds of this State at- a rate of interest from 5% to 7%, which would be of great benefit to the com - munities who are now having issues of bonds for which there is no market. The rate of interest on the securities purchased at this time would off-set the discount, besides having the funds invested within our State. FISCAL AGENCY It would appear that the Legislature for the year 1917 passed a law making the County Treasurer the Fiscal Agent for the several counties, but, it would seem that, while this law was passed, the State Treasurer has been doing the business for the Fiscal Department of the State. I have the honor to report that this Department handled in receipts and disbursements approximately two million dollars dur - ing the last biennium, and I would recommend that the law of 1917 be repealed and a new law be passed making the State Treasurer the Fiscal Agent of the State. After looking into the matter, I find that Nebraska is the only State having a condition of this kind, as it ls> generally conceded in the many states that the State Treasurer is the Fiscal Agent. I think it would be more of a business proposition as the parties holding bonds outside of our State would prefer to send them to the State Treasurer. There would be no objection to the School District or municipality making them payable, if they shoulc wish, at the County Treasurer's office in the County where the bonds have been issued. APPROPRIATIONS This Department will need the following appropriations to cover expenses for two more years: TRUST FUNDS OF THE STATE It will be noted from the detailed statements following that the Trust Funds have increased during the biennium $576,692.59. Respectfully submitted, D. B. CROPSEY, State Treasurer. Salaries _. _ _ _ _ _ _. ■■■■■I 11 ■■■■■ II ■■■■■■■■ I * 5,360.00 2,500.00 treasurer's and Deputy's Bonds incidentals Total | $41,860.00
